elements.content: We describe herein the highly selective semihydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene using a Zr-based metal–organic framework (MOF; NU-1000) with Cu–oxo clusters present on the nodes as precatalysts. The active form of the catalyst is MOF-supported Cu nanoparticles generated in situ upon a brief H2 reduction treatment at 200 °C. This composite material is stable for many catalytic cycles and effectively avoids overreduction to ethane, a common problem for many semihydrogenation catalysts.
elements.clean_text: We describe herein the highly selective semihydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene using a Zr-based metal-organic framework (MOF; NU-1000) with Cu-oxo clusters present on the nodes as precatalysts. The active form of the catalyst is MOF-supported Cu nanoparticles generated in situ upon a brief H2 reduction treatment at 200 °C. This composite material is stable for many catalytic cycles and effectively avoids overreduction to ethane, a common problem for many semihydrogenation catalysts.

elements.content: Polyethylene production for thermoplastics is the second-largest downstream chemical process worldwide. These industrial polymerization reactions utilize Ziegler–Natta catalysts that are extremely sensitive to poisoning by alkynes. Therefore, acetylene contamination in ethylene from upstream processes must be removed prior to the polymerization process. In lieu of costly distillations to purify the mixture, conversion of acetylene to ethylene through semihydrogenationthat is, the partial reduction of an alkyne to an alkeneis an attractive approach because it removes the contaminant while simultaneously producing more of the desired compound. However, exquisite catalyst selectivity is required to prevent the overreduction of acetylene and undesired consumption of ethylene in this process. Materials consisting of transition-metal active sites (Fe and Ni) or noble-metal catalysts such as Pd with Au, Ag, or Ga dopants to attenuate the reactivity and improve the selectivity have been developed for this purpose; however, overreduction remains problematic, with ∼10% ethane production typical for industrial catalysts and conditions. With higher earth abundancy than precious metal catalysts, supported Cu catalysts have garnered increasing attention for many applications where the activity and product selectivity can be finely tuned via active-site size modulation. Notably, Cu surfaces have demonstrated a propensity to interact strongly with acetylene gas, with recent computational support for the importance of the metal cluster size on the reactivity of Cu catalysts.
elements.clean_text: Polyethylene production for thermoplastics is the second-largest downstream chemical process worldwide. These industrial polymerization reactions utilize Ziegler-Natta catalysts that are extremely sensitive to poisoning by alkynes. Therefore, acetylene contamination in ethylene from upstream processes must be removed prior to the polymerization process. In lieu of costly distillations to purify the mixture, conversion of acetylene to ethylene through semihydrogenationthat is, the partial reduction of an alkyne to an alkeneis an attractive approach because it removes the contaminant while simultaneously producing more of the desired compound. However, exquisite catalyst selectivity is required to prevent the overreduction of acetylene and undesired consumption of ethylene in this process. Materials consisting of transition-metal active sites (Fe and Ni) or noble-metal catalysts such as Pd with Au, Ag, or Ga dopants to attenuate the reactivity and improve the selectivity have been developed for this purpose; however, overreduction remains problematic, with ~10% ethane production typical for industrial catalysts and conditions. With higher earth abundancy than precious metal catalysts, supported Cu catalysts have garnered increasing attention for many applications where the activity and product selectivity can be finely tuned via active-site size modulation. Notably, Cu surfaces have demonstrated a propensity to interact strongly with acetylene gas, with recent computational support for the importance of the metal cluster size on the reactivity of Cu catalysts.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), hybrid materials composed of inorganic nodes linked via organic ligands forming 2D and 3D extended structures, exhibit great potential in developing supported catalysts because of their highly tunable nature and porosity. In addition to the built-in functionalities incorporated from de novosynthesis, postsynthetic modifications can impart various properties to these materials. Because of their high thermal and chemical stability, Zr-based MOFs can be subjected to harsh experimental conditions and reactive chemicals (such as water and hydrogen sulfide), allowing a variety of metal oxide or sulfide clusters to be anchored to the Zr6 nodes via atomic layer deposition or solvothermal impregnation. The crystallinity of MOFs enables the use of a suite of characterization techniques to elucidate the structure of the anchored species, while their robust stability and tremendous porosity lends them well to applications requiring exposure to water vapor, air, and other gases at a wide range of temperatures.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), hybrid materials composed of inorganic nodes linked via organic ligands forming 2D and 3D extended structures, exhibit great potential in developing supported catalysts because of their highly tunable nature and porosity. In addition to the built-in functionalities incorporated from  de novosynthesis, postsynthetic modifications can impart various properties to these materials. Because of their high thermal and chemical stability, Zr-based MOFs can be subjected to harsh experimental conditions and reactive chemicals (such as water and hydrogen sulfide), allowing a variety of metal oxide or sulfide clusters to be anchored to the Zr6 nodes via atomic layer deposition or solvothermal impregnation. The crystallinity of MOFs enables the use of a suite of characterization techniques to elucidate the structure of the anchored species, while their robust stability and tremendous porosity lends them well to applications requiring exposure to water vapor, air, and other gases at a wide range of temperatures.

elements.content: One such Zr-based MOF, NU-1000, is a mesoporous material consisting of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(H2O)4(OH)4 nodes and tetratopic 1,3,6,8-tetrakis­(p-benzoate)­pyrene (TBAPy4–) linkers. Upon metalation with Cu­(dmap)2 [dmap = (dimethylamino)-2-propoxide], Cu–oxo clusters are uniformly anchored to the Zr6 node of NU-1000 in high density. Following mild reduction in a flow of H2, Cu nanoparticles form inside the pores of NU-1000, resulting in a composite material (CuNPs@NU-1000) that has been extensively characterized using difference envelope density, pair distribution function (PDF) analysis, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in a previous report. This material was shown to consist of two populations of Cu0 nanoparticles, with diameters of <1 and ∼4 nm residing in the hexagonal and triangular channels of NU-1000 (). The reported PDF exhibits features characteristic of face-centered-cubic packing beyond an interatomic distance of 30 Å, indicating that the large particles are not the result of aggregation. The sizes of these particles are posited to be templated by the pores of the MOF. In addition to structural characterization, initial catalytic experiments revealed that CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits sluggish activity for the reduction of ethylene. Considering the strong adsorption of acetylene on Cu surfaces and the relative inertness of CuNPs@NU-1000 toward ethylene under reducing conditions, we hypothesized that this material would be a highly selective acetylene semihydrogenation catalyst. Herein, we report the catalytic performance of this composite material for hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. Notably, CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits excellent ethylene selectivity under conditions that simulate industrially relevant reactant mixtures (<3% acetylene in ethylene).
elements.clean_text: One such Zr-based MOF, NU-1000, is a mesoporous material consisting of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(H2O)4(OH)4 nodes and tetratopic 1,3,6,8-tetrakis(p-benzoate)pyrene (TBAPy4-) linkers. Upon metalation with Cu(dmap)2 [dmap = (dimethylamino)-2-propoxide], Cu-oxo clusters are uniformly anchored to the Zr6 node of NU-1000 in high density. Following mild reduction in a flow of H2, Cu nanoparticles form inside the pores of NU-1000, resulting in a composite material (CuNPs@NU-1000) that has been extensively characterized using difference envelope density, pair distribution function (PDF) analysis, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in a previous report. This material was shown to consist of two populations of Cu0 nanoparticles, with diameters of <1 and ~4 nm residing in the hexagonal and triangular channels of NU-1000 (). The reported PDF exhibits features characteristic of face-centered-cubic packing beyond an interatomic distance of 30 Å, indicating that the large particles are not the result of aggregation. The sizes of these particles are posited to be templated by the pores of the MOF. In addition to structural characterization, initial catalytic experiments revealed that CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits sluggish activity for the reduction of ethylene. Considering the strong adsorption of acetylene on Cu surfaces and the relative inertness of CuNPs@NU-1000 toward ethylene under reducing conditions, we hypothesized that this material would be a highly selective acetylene semihydrogenation catalyst. Herein, we report the catalytic performance of this composite material for hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. Notably, CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits excellent ethylene selectivity under conditions that simulate industrially relevant reactant mixtures (<3% acetylene in ethylene).

elements.content: Installation of Cu–oxo clusters in NU-1000, followed by mild reduction, yielding Cu nanoparticles with diameters of ∼4 and <1 nm.
elements.clean_text: 1  Installation of Cu-oxo clusters in NU-1000, followed by mild reduction, yielding Cu nanoparticles with diameters of ~4 and <1 nm.

elements.content: NU-1000 was synthesized and acid-activated according to a previously reported procedure. Cu–oxo clusters were incorporated through a solvothermal deposition in MOFs (SIM) procedure using Cu­(dmap)2 as the metal source, yielding a material denoted as Cu-SIM-NU-1000. The crystallinity of the MOF is maintained throughout this process, as observed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; see Figure S3). The nitrogen isotherm obtained at 77 K reveals that the porosity of the material is in good accordance with previously reported values (see Figure S4). Analysis of metal loadings in digested samples using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry reveals a Cu loading of 5.9 ± 0.3 Cu per node. The XPS spectrum of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 exhibits signals characteristic of Cu2+, which disappear upon the formation of CuNPs@NU-1000 under 2% H2 at 200 °C, indicating the successful reduction of the Cu species (see Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: NU-1000 was synthesized and acid-activated according to a previously reported procedure. Cu-oxo clusters were incorporated through a solvothermal deposition in MOFs (SIM) procedure using Cu(dmap)2 as the metal source, yielding a material denoted as Cu-SIM-NU-1000. The crystallinity of the MOF is maintained throughout this process, as observed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; see Figure S3). The nitrogen isotherm obtained at 77 K reveals that the porosity of the material is in good accordance with previously reported values (see Figure S4). Analysis of metal loadings in digested samples using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry reveals a Cu loading of 5.9 ± 0.3 Cu per node. The XPS spectrum of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 exhibits signals characteristic of Cu2+, which disappear upon the formation of CuNPs@NU-1000 under 2% H2 at 200 °C, indicating the successful reduction of the Cu species (see Figure S5).

elements.content: Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that 11-atom Cu clusters are excellent candidates for high ethylene selectivity during the acetylene hydrogenation process. With subnanometer Cu clustersestimated to consist of 12 Cu atomsresiding in the small triangular pores of CuNPs@NU-1000, we set out to test this material for the semihydrogenation of acetylene. In a typical reaction, 10 mg of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 and approximately 200 mg of quartz sand were mixed and loaded into a stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor. A stream of 5% H2 in Ar was fed over the catalyst bed at 200 °C for 6 h to facilitate the reduction of Cu–oxo clusters and the formation of Cu nanoparticles. Upon cofeeding of acetylene gas with 5 equiv of H2, a distribution of ethylene, ethane, and C4 byproducts (1-butene and 1,3-butadiene) were observed during the reaction. Experiments in which the amount of H2 was reduced to 3 or 1 equiv reveal that semihydrogenation proceeds without excess H2 gas, so further experiments were conducted with a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2.
elements.clean_text: Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that 11-atom Cu clusters are excellent candidates for high ethylene selectivity during the acetylene hydrogenation process. With subnanometer Cu clustersestimated to consist of 12 Cu atomsresiding in the small triangular pores of CuNPs@NU-1000, we set out to test this material for the semihydrogenation of acetylene. In a typical reaction, 10 mg of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 and approximately 200 mg of quartz sand were mixed and loaded into a stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor. A stream of 5% H2 in Ar was fed over the catalyst bed at 200 °C for 6 h to facilitate the reduction of Cu-oxo clusters and the formation of Cu nanoparticles. Upon cofeeding of acetylene gas with 5 equiv of H2, a distribution of ethylene, ethane, and C4 byproducts (1-butene and 1,3-butadiene) were observed during the reaction. Experiments in which the amount of H2 was reduced to 3 or 1 equiv reveal that semihydrogenation proceeds without excess H2 gas, so further experiments were conducted with a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2.

elements.content: To determine the turnover frequency (TOF) of CuNPs@NU-1000, reaction conditions were further optimized to limit the acetylene conversion to below 10%. When the contact time of acetylene is varied with the catalyst (W/F, where W is moles of Cu and F is the molar flow rate of acetylene) while a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2 is maintained, the TOF (on a per Cu basis) for this process is determined to be 100 ± 20 h–1 (a, blue). Prior characterization of this material indicates that roughly half of the Cu atoms are on the surface of the particles, giving a TOF of 200 ± 50 h–1 on a per surface Cu atom basis. Under these reaction conditions, the overreduction to ethane was limited to <1%. This reactivity profile was maintained throughout a 24 h stability test (b, blue) in which CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits a constant catalytic performance over extended reaction times. Cu supported by high-surface-area zirconia (∼270 m2 g–1) was studied as a control material that mimics the Zr nodes of Cu-SIM-NU-1000. This material initially exhibits a TOF (per Cu basis) of 45 ± 1 h–1; however, the reactivity drops by 20% over the course of 24 h (, black). This demonstrates that CuNPs@NU-1000 has activity and stability superior to those of Cu on zirconia.
elements.clean_text: To determine the turnover frequency (TOF) of CuNPs@NU-1000, reaction conditions were further optimized to limit the acetylene conversion to below 10%. When the contact time of acetylene is varied with the catalyst (W/F, where W is moles of Cu and F is the molar flow rate of acetylene) while a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2 is maintained, the TOF (on a per Cu basis) for this process is determined to be 100 ± 20 h-1 (a, blue). Prior characterization of this material indicates that roughly half of the Cu atoms are on the surface of the particles, giving a TOF of 200 ± 50 h-1 on a per surface Cu atom basis. Under these reaction conditions, the overreduction to ethane was limited to <1%. This reactivity profile was maintained throughout a 24 h stability test (b, blue) in which CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits a constant catalytic performance over extended reaction times. Cu supported by high-surface-area zirconia (~270 m2 g-1) was studied as a control material that mimics the Zr nodes of Cu-SIM-NU-1000. This material initially exhibits a TOF (per Cu basis) of 45 ± 1 h-1; however, the reactivity drops by 20% over the course of 24 h (, black). This demonstrates that CuNPs@NU-1000 has activity and stability superior to those of Cu on zirconia.

elements.content: Acetylene semihydrogenation at 200 °C catalyzed by CuNPs@NU-1000 and Cu on zirconia. (a) W/F study to calculate the TOF and (b) 24 h stability test.
elements.clean_text: 2  Acetylene semihydrogenation at 200 °C catalyzed by CuNPs@NU-1000 and Cu on zirconia. (a) W/F study to calculate the TOF and (b) 24 h stability test.

elements.content: We attribute the enhanced activity and stability of CuNPs@NU-1000 to the prevention of nanoparticle aggregation due to their confinement within the pores of the MOF support. This is a well-established phenomenon for composite materials consisting of nanoparticles entrapped within MOF pores. To test this hypothesis, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of each material were collected after 24 h on stream. HAADF-STEM of recovered CuNPs@NU-1000 reveals the presence of nanoparticles between 2 and 4 nm with no large aggregates (a,b), which agrees with prior PDF analysis of Cu supported in NU-1000, further supporting our proposed catalyst structure. Contrarily, HAADF-STEM of the control material (Cu supported on zirconia) reveals larger particles and significant aggregation (c,d). This stark contrast reinforces our hypothesis that the MOF support maintains well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles and prevents deleterious aggregation.
elements.clean_text: We attribute the enhanced activity and stability of CuNPs@NU-1000 to the prevention of nanoparticle aggregation due to their confinement within the pores of the MOF support. This is a well-established phenomenon for composite materials consisting of nanoparticles entrapped within MOF pores. To test this hypothesis, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of each material were collected after 24 h on stream. HAADF-STEM of recovered CuNPs@NU-1000 reveals the presence of nanoparticles between 2 and 4 nm with no large aggregates (a,b), which agrees with prior PDF analysis of Cu supported in NU-1000, further supporting our proposed catalyst structure. Contrarily, HAADF-STEM of the control material (Cu supported on zirconia) reveals larger particles and significant aggregation (c,d). This stark contrast reinforces our hypothesis that the MOF support maintains well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles and prevents deleterious aggregation.

elements.content: HAADF-STEM images of (a and b) CuNPs@NU-1000 after catalysis and (c and d) Cu supported on zirconia after catalysis.
elements.clean_text: 3  HAADF-STEM images of (a and b) CuNPs@NU-1000 after catalysis and (c and d) Cu supported on zirconia after catalysis.

elements.content: While developing conditions to determine the TOF, we observed a correlation between the conversion of acetylene and the proportion of C4 compounds (1-butene and 1,3-butadiene) in the product distribution (see Figure S1). At very high conversions (>95%), undesired side products comprise roughly 15 mol % of the product stream, although ethane production is still suppressed (<2%). To understand the possible sources for the observed C4 byproducts, ethylene was cofed with acetylene and H2 in the reactant stream at a low flow rate to facilitate high conversion of acetylene. Increasing the concentration of ethylene did not impact the amount of C4 products, indicating that these byproducts are primarily the result of acetylene dimerization rather than deleterious reactions involving ethylene. In fact, under conditions that simulate the industrially relevant removal of acetylene from ethylene (97% ethylene and 3% acetylene reactant stream), we observed the complete consumption of acetylene while maintaining a very high purity of ethylene (>99.5%). Ethane and C4 byproducts together comprise <0.5 mol % of the product stream under these conditions, illustrating the tremendous selectivity of the CuNPs@NU-1000 catalyst.
elements.clean_text: While developing conditions to determine the TOF, we observed a correlation between the conversion of acetylene and the proportion of C4 compounds (1-butene and 1,3-butadiene) in the product distribution (see Figure S1). At very high conversions (>95%), undesired side products comprise roughly 15 mol % of the product stream, although ethane production is still suppressed (<2%). To understand the possible sources for the observed C4 byproducts, ethylene was cofed with acetylene and H2 in the reactant stream at a low flow rate to facilitate high conversion of acetylene. Increasing the concentration of ethylene did not impact the amount of C4 products, indicating that these byproducts are primarily the result of acetylene dimerization rather than deleterious reactions involving ethylene. In fact, under conditions that simulate the industrially relevant removal of acetylene from ethylene (97% ethylene and 3% acetylene reactant stream), we observed the complete consumption of acetylene while maintaining a very high purity of ethylene (>99.5%). Ethane and C4 byproducts together comprise <0.5 mol % of the product stream under these conditions, illustrating the tremendous selectivity of the CuNPs@NU-1000 catalyst.

elements.content: This propensity for semihydrogenation can be rationalized by computational work on the hydrogenation of acetylene and ethylene over graphene-supported Cu clusters, which are structurally similar to the subnanometer Cu particles surrounded by pyrene-based linkers in CuNPs@NU-1000. We propose two factors that contribute to the observed reactivity. First, the adsorption of acetylene to the Cu cluster surface is significantly more energetically favorable than the adsorption of ethylene. Therefore, the formed ethylene is readily replaced by another acetylene molecule before overreduction to ethane can occur, favoring the semihydrogenation product, especially under low conversion conditions where the acetylene concentration is high. Second, the computational results indicate that the rate-limiting step for acetylene hydrogenation is reductive elimination of the surface-bound vinyl intermediate with a copper hydride species. At high acetylene conversions, dimerization can occur through the undesired reductive elimination of two neighboring vinyl species that are present in high surface coverage, resulting in more C4 byproducts ().
elements.clean_text: This propensity for semihydrogenation can be rationalized by computational work on the hydrogenation of acetylene and ethylene over graphene-supported Cu clusters, which are structurally similar to the subnanometer Cu particles surrounded by pyrene-based linkers in CuNPs@NU-1000. We propose two factors that contribute to the observed reactivity. First, the adsorption of acetylene to the Cu cluster surface is significantly more energetically favorable than the adsorption of ethylene. Therefore, the formed ethylene is readily replaced by another acetylene molecule before overreduction to ethane can occur, favoring the semihydrogenation product, especially under low conversion conditions where the acetylene concentration is high. Second, the computational results indicate that the rate-limiting step for acetylene hydrogenation is reductive elimination of the surface-bound vinyl intermediate with a copper hydride species. At high acetylene conversions, dimerization can occur through the undesired reductive elimination of two neighboring vinyl species that are present in high surface coverage, resulting in more C4 byproducts ().

elements.content: Proposed mechanism of the acetylene reduction and potential for dimerization.
elements.clean_text: 4  Proposed mechanism of the acetylene reduction and potential for dimerization.

elements.content: To determine if CuNPs@NU-1000 maintains the overall MOF structure and porosity after semihydrogenation, the catalyst was recovered from the reactor and separated from the quartz sand for characterization. PXRD analysis of this recovered material aligns well with as-synthesized NU-1000 and Cu-SIM-NU-1000 with the addition of a minor peak assigned to the quartz wool support used in the reactor (see Figure S3). In addition, N2 isotherm analysis shows a drop in the accessible porosity of the material, consistent with other reports of recovered MOF catalysts (see Figure S4). This decrease is likely due to the residual low-surface-area silica used to dilute the sample in the reactor and the blockage of some pores by nanoparticles during formation of the active catalyst. The material remains a free-flowing powder after catalysis, showing no signs of sintering after several days on stream.
elements.clean_text: To determine if CuNPs@NU-1000 maintains the overall MOF structure and porosity after semihydrogenation, the catalyst was recovered from the reactor and separated from the quartz sand for characterization. PXRD analysis of this recovered material aligns well with as-synthesized NU-1000 and Cu-SIM-NU-1000 with the addition of a minor peak assigned to the quartz wool support used in the reactor (see Figure S3). In addition, N2 isotherm analysis shows a drop in the accessible porosity of the material, consistent with other reports of recovered MOF catalysts (see Figure S4). This decrease is likely due to the residual low-surface-area silica used to dilute the sample in the reactor and the blockage of some pores by nanoparticles during formation of the active catalyst. The material remains a free-flowing powder after catalysis, showing no signs of sintering after several days on stream.

elements.content: In summary, we report a Cu nanoparticle–MOF composite material (CuNPs@NU-1000) as a highly selective catalyst for the semihydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene with excellent activity and stability. Of particular note, this catalyst demonstrates outstanding selectivity under conditions that simulate the industrial removal of acetylene contamination from ethylene (97% ethylene and 3% acetylene), with minimal overreduction to ethane and undesired dimerization (<0.5 mol % byproducts). We ascribe the catalytic performance of CuNPs@NU-1000 to the uniform size of the active copper sites and inhibition of nanoparticle aggregation due to the templating effect of the structurally well-defined NU-1000 support. Because of the tunability of MOF supports, future work involving the investigation of how this templating effect impacts the particle size and catalytic performance of these composite materials is in progress in our laboratories, and we will report on the progress in due course.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report a Cu nanoparticle-MOF composite material (CuNPs@NU-1000) as a highly selective catalyst for the semihydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene with excellent activity and stability. Of particular note, this catalyst demonstrates outstanding selectivity under conditions that simulate the industrial removal of acetylene contamination from ethylene (97% ethylene and 3% acetylene), with minimal overreduction to ethane and undesired dimerization (<0.5 mol % byproducts). We ascribe the catalytic performance of CuNPs@NU-1000 to the uniform size of the active copper sites and inhibition of nanoparticle aggregation due to the templating effect of the structurally well-defined NU-1000 support. Because of the tunability of MOF supports, future work involving the investigation of how this templating effect impacts the particle size and catalytic performance of these composite materials is in progress in our laboratories, and we will report on the progress in due course.

cln_elements.content: Density functional theory calculations demonstrate that 11-atom Cu clusters are excellent candidates for high ethylene selectivity during the acetylene hydrogenation process. With subnanometer Cu clustersestimated to consist of 12 Cu atomsresiding in the small triangular pores of CuNPs@NU-1000, we set out to test this material for the semihydrogenation of acetylene. In a typical reaction, 10 mg of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 and approximately 200 mg of quartz sand were mixed and loaded into a stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor. A stream of 5% H2 in Ar was fed over the catalyst bed at 200 °C for 6 h to facilitate the reduction of Cu–oxo clusters and the formation of Cu nanoparticles. Upon cofeeding of acetylene gas with 5 equiv of H2, a distribution of ethylene, ethane, and C4 byproducts (1-butene and 1,3-butadiene) were observed during the reaction. Experiments in which the amount of H2 was reduced to 3 or 1 equiv reveal that semihydrogenation proceeds without excess H2 gas, so further experiments were conducted with a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2.

With subnanometer Cu clustersestimated to consist of 12 Cu atomsresiding in the small triangular pores of CuNPs@NU-1000, we set out to test this material for the semihydrogenation of acetylene. In a typical reaction, 10 mg of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 and approximately 200 mg of quartz sand were mixed and loaded into a stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor. A stream of 5% H2 in Ar was fed over the catalyst bed at 200 °C for 6 h to facilitate the reduction of Cu-oxo clusters and the formation of Cu nanoparticles. Upon cofeeding of acetylene gas with 5 equiv of H2, a distribution of ethylene, ethane, and C4 byproducts (1-butene and 1,3-butadiene) were observed during the reaction. Experiments in which the amount of H2 was reduced to 3 or 1 equiv reveal that semihydrogenation proceeds without excess H2 gas, so further experiments were conducted with a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2.

cln_elements.content:
NU-1000 was synthesized and acid-activated according to a previously reported procedure. Cu–oxo clusters were incorporated through a solvothermal deposition in MOFs (SIM) procedure using Cu­(dmap)2 as the metal source, yielding a material denoted as Cu-SIM-NU-1000. The crystallinity of the MOF is maintained throughout this process, as observed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; see Figure S3). The nitrogen isotherm obtained at 77 K reveals that the porosity of the material is in good accordance with previously reported values (see Figure S4). Analysis of metal loadings in digested samples using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry reveals a Cu loading of 5.9 ± 0.3 Cu per node. The XPS spectrum of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 exhibits signals characteristic of Cu2+, which disappear upon the formation of CuNPs@NU-1000 under 2% H2 at 200 °C, indicating the successful reduction of the Cu species (see Figure S5).

To determine the turnover frequency (TOF) of CuNPs@NU-1000, reaction conditions were further optimized to limit the acetylene conversion to below 10%. When the contact time of acetylene is varied with the catalyst (W/F, where W is moles of Cu and F is the molar flow rate of acetylene) while a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2 is maintained, the TOF (on a per Cu basis) for this process is determined to be 100 ± 20 h–1 (a, blue). Prior characterization of this material indicates that roughly half of the Cu atoms are on the surface of the particles, giving a TOF of 200 ± 50 h–1 on a per surface Cu atom basis. Under these reaction conditions, the overreduction to ethane was limited to <1%. This reactivity profile was maintained throughout a 24 h stability test (b, blue) in which CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits a constant catalytic performance over extended reaction times. Cu supported by high-surface-area zirconia (∼270 m2 g–1) was studied as a control material that mimics the Zr nodes of Cu-SIM-NU-1000. This material initially exhibits a TOF (per Cu basis) of 45 ± 1 h–1; however, the reactivity drops by 20% over the course of 24 h (, black). This demonstrates that CuNPs@NU-1000 has activity and stability superior to those of Cu on zirconia.

The XPS spectrum of Cu-SIM-NU-1000 exhibits signals characteristic of Cu2+, which disappear upon the formation of CuNPs@NU-1000 under 2% H2 at 200 °C, indicating the successful reduction of the Cu species (see Figure S5). 

To determine the turnover frequency (TOF) of CuNPs@NU-1000, reaction conditions were further optimized to limit the acetylene conversion to below 10%. When the contact time of acetylene is varied with the catalyst (W/F, where W is moles of Cu and F is the molar flow rate of acetylene) while a 1:1 ratio of acetylene and H2 is maintained, the TOF (on a per Cu basis) for this process is determined to be 100 ± 20 h-1 (a, blue). Prior characterization of this material indicates that roughly half of the Cu atoms are on the surface of the particles, giving a TOF of 200 ± 50 h-1 on a per surface Cu atom basis. Under these reaction conditions, the overreduction to ethane was limited to <1%. This reactivity profile was maintained throughout a 24 h stability test (b, blue) in which CuNPs@NU-1000 exhibits a constant catalytic performance over extended reaction times. Cu supported by high-surface-area zirconia (~270 m2 g-1) was studied as a control material that mimics the Zr nodes of Cu-SIM-NU-1000. This material initially exhibits a TOF (per Cu basis) of 45 ± 1 h-1; however, the reactivity drops by 20% over the course of 24 h (, black). This demonstrates that CuNPs@NU-1000 has activity and stability superior to those of Cu on zirconia.

catalytic activity.condition: half of the Cu atoms are on the surface of the particles

metadata.title:
Highly Selective Acetylene Semihydrogenation Catalyzed
by Cu Nanoparticles Supported in a Metal–Organic Framework
